abstract:
In summary, the Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) aimed to improve rainbow trout populations and Tribal harvest opportunities by restoring stream habitats on the Colville Confederated Tribes reservation. However, a review in 2011 revealed that previous efforts lacked statistical rigor and clarity in prioritizing restoration actions. To address these shortcomings, a new approach called Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) was developed.

EDT is an analytical model that focuses on restoring natural stream function and has a clear prioritization strategy. It uses empirical observations of current habitat conditions, fish use, and an EDT model to identify the areas with the greatest potential for improving fish performance. The development of the EDT model involves rating Level II attributes based on empirical data and established stream habitat inventory methods.

The necessity of this approach is that it provides a systematic and data-driven method for identifying priority areas for habitat restoration and protection, ensuring that resources are allocated effectively to maximize the benefits for rainbow trout populations and Tribal harvest opportunities. By focusing on natural stream functions and using empirical data, EDT addresses the issues raised in the 2011 review regarding the lack of statistical rigor and haphazard prioritization of restoration actions.

There is no code included in this answer as it is a high-level summary of the method and its necessity.

description:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP), initiated in 1990, aimed to enhance the survival of migratory rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) and improve harvest opportunities for the Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) through habitat restoration and riparian corridor rehabilitation (LeCaire and Peone, 1991). This project targeted streams on the CCT reservation to restore healthy and harvestable salmonid populations.

The evaluation of LRHIP accomplishments in 2011, as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committees Categorical Review process, revealed that while significant progress had been made regarding habitat conditions and monitoring trends in rainbow trout populations (LeCaire and Peone, 1991), the methods employed for both aspects lacked clarity. The monitoring study designs required statistical rigor improvement, and the prioritization strategy for habitat restoration actions was unclear.

To address these shortcomings, a new approach to habitat restoration and protection was developed focusing on restoring natural stream function and implementing a well-defined prioritization strategy (Anonymous, 2011). An Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model was employed to help determine the highest priority areas for habitat restoration and protection.

The EDT model is an analytical framework that combines empirical observations of habitat conditions and fish use with local expertise and other models and analyses to identify reaches and habitat attributes likely to have the greatest benefit for improving fish performance (Lichatowic et al., 1995; Lestel√© et al., 1996; Mobrand et al., 1997, 1998). The model uses a rating system for Level II attributes, with the highest confidence attributed to those based on empirical data.

To apply this methodology, an established stream habitat inventory protocol was selected that could be readily adapted to EDT Level II attribute ratings and provided a template for independently assessing reach form and function (Anonymous, 2011). Data collected following this protocol are used for Level II attribute rating as described in Protocol ID: 685 (Sanpoil and Upper Columbia Subbasin Stream Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment Modeling).

To inventory stream habitat suitable for adfluvial redband rainbow trout, it is essential to identify natural and anthropogenic barriers affecting all life stages. Natural barriers can include physical obstructions such as waterfalls, rapids, and bedrock outcroppings. Anthropogenic barriers may involve human activities, such as dams, weirs, or channelization. Barriers impacting redband rainbow trout can affect their ability to migrate, reproduce, or grow, ultimately hindering population recovery and productivity.

To ensure a thorough analysis, it is recommended to carefully evaluate each reach of the identified streams using the established protocol and EDT model to assess its form and function accurately. This approach will enable the identification of specific areas requiring habitat restoration or protection efforts, ultimately leading to more effective and targeted conservation strategies for redband rainbow trout populations.
